content.description: Head up the somewhat loose starting rock to a small headwall.  Surmount this headwall to gain a sloping ledge.  From here head to the top.  Rock quality can be an issue on the second half of this pitch so be wary. Long pitch!
content.location: Located on the right flanks of the 7-11 crag. This route is the second to last route before heading up a small hill to the Obscurity Crags.

content.description:
A fun, techical corner leads to the large bench. Head left and finish on the thin vertical seam and a slight, easy run to the chains.

The bottom can also be linked into the fun upper half of YPA for a longer pitch.

In loving memory of Ted Morris.
content.location: A jug horn starts at the base of the corner between Quick Tease and Poseidon.

content.description: One of the few under appreciated gear lines at Allenspur, Spur Corner climbs in the corner in between French Connection and Flake Fest.  While it is a bit dirty in spots due to low traffic it is worth hauling the small amount of gear up the hill to do this climb.
content.protection: 2-3 small cams (#2 c3 useful) Doubles in the .3  - .75 C4's and Singles 1-3.  A selection of smaller nuts would be helpful as well.  Protects decently although sometimes the gear can be hard to figure out.  Bolted chain anchor.  Climbed fine on a 70m but I would be a little nervous only using a 50m as this is one of the tallest climbs on the wall.
content.location: Located in the corner between French Connection and Flake Fest.  Most obvious trad line when approaching the 7-11 crag on the new approach.

content.description:
Great line. A huge move to and hard match on a crimp rail by the second bolt (first crux) lead to excellent flowing moves to pull left over the gray bulge (think "sidepulls") up to a rest in a prominent horizontal. From here launch into a sequential and final crux travere right with positive crimps but terrible feet to a decent pod right of the last bolt. If the pump hasn't got you by now, make a few easier moves to the anchors.

Fairly hard at the traverse but some mental acuity and attentive footwork/body positions will get you through. Keep in mind you pull the crux moves some 4-6 feet above your last bolt, but that only adds to the fun, right?!
content.location: Leftmost route on the vertical wall containing the Dam in the rain arete. Just right of the grey slab containing Jens and Gobis in the Dark

content.description: This dirty corner sports a bolt or two and is rarely climbed. The corner crack has a lot of potential, but as it's equipped it requires suspect gear and a lot of scrubbing.
content.protection: A single to #3 rack with spare draws.
content.location: This corner is to the right of Flake Fest.  Look for dirt, choss, and a high bolt up to the left, half-way through the route.

content.description: This short route tackles the small roof and grey face just uphill of Rancho Deluxe.  A tenuous mantle (if you don't grab the tree) guards the chains, which are set back slightly from the face.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with maillons.
content.location: Left and 15 feet uphill of Rancho Deluxe.

content.description: A burly route that requires all the core power you have this goes straight up the overhanging arete and is fairly brutal the whole way up.  Fingerlocks at the top cement the experience.
content.location: About middle way on the 7-11 crag this route ascends the obvious steep arete.

content.description: Short and sweet! The bolted arete between Gobis and Short Stuff.
content.location: Far left side of 7-11. The last arete.

content.description: This right trending route traverses some flakes up to sidepulls and crimps up high.  Can be a little hard to read at first.
content.location: This route starts at the toe of the 7-11 buttress if headed towards the obscurity crags.  Identified by the flake directly off the ground and is to the right of a dirtyish looking crack with three bolts.

content.description: A great route that follows a very enjoyable flake up a relatively steep wall.  A stick clip would not be a bad idea for the first bolt because a fall would land you in talus.  The crux is just getting to that first bolt.
content.location: Starts in the middle of the wall just to the right of Jens and Gobi.  Your belayer will basically be standing in the trees.

content.description: Neat route that works it's way up the ridge on the right hand side of 7-11 crag. Great views (hence the name), easy climbing, has a mini alpine ridge like feel. Crux is right off the ground. After the 3rd bolt, move left out onto the west face, then aim straight up towards the chains.
content.location: Far right side of 7-11 crag. Don't scramble up the eroding gully. Walk another 60 feet to the south, and then cut back left on a faint trail.

content.description: Follows the same rock up as Gobis in the Dark over lower angle slab with several ledges.
content.location: Directly to the right of Gobis in the Dark.  Follows the same rock up the lower angle slab with several ledges.

content.description: Wanders up somewhat looser rock over some small ledges to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: The first route that you hit on the wall if you are coming up the switchbacks.

content.description: This line ascends up through several faces interspersed with great rest ledges.
content.location: Ascends the slab just to the left of Flakefest.  First thing you come upon if you take the lower trail to the 7-11 crag.

content.description: A fantastic route that goes up one of the most classic flakes and splitters out at Allenspur.  All bolted due to the flakes somewhat delicate nature.  No individual move is that difficult but it is one of the more sustained routes out here.  Go send it!
content.location: If taking the lower approach this is the climb that will be at the end of the trail.

content.description:
Start up the obvious arete sidepulling on seams and using small edges to gain a good edge (crux). After clipping the 2nd bolt transfer around the arete to the right onto the face and continue up using the arete with your left hand and a juggy crack for your right. Committed, balancy movement, a heel hook or two, some slaps/compression.... good route.

Enjoyable movement and one of the more pure arete routes in the area. Fun and totally worth it. Would get 4 stars if not for a small tree all up in your business at the top.
content.location: Uphill from Rancho Deluxe, the obvious sharp arete before the Gobi/Jens section.

content.description:
an enjoyable route that wanders up various weaknesses on a steep slab. A steep start on good holds leads to a couple interesting pulls up to a small ledge. From here, an insecure move with bad feet (crux) to a good jug and clipping stance guards a romp up the final face.

Feels longer than it is. Nice and sustained, with some interesting movement.
content.protection: Bolts to cold shuts. All in good shape. I believe there were 9.
content.location: Between French Connection and Rancho Deluxe.
